data.title: Things to do in Mumbai today
data.meta_description: Check out what can you do in Mumbai today.
data.text:
BOOK NOW - HAPI Brewing Co

Check out what can you do in Mumbai today.

Pick between two comedy gigs

SAB SCAM HAI

Comedian Gaurav Kapoor will take a dig at everything — from ’90s nostalgia to food and hygiene issues — in this show. The Delhi-born, Mumbai-based comic is known for his observational style of comedy. However, this show will be a mix of observational and storytelling style of humour. In 2015, he was the opening act for popular comedian Russell Peters’ Almost Famous world tour in Delhi. For Sab Scam Hain, Kapoor “tries to find scam in all the happy and nostalgic things in life”. WHERE: Above The Habitat, Khar WHEN: 8 pm and 10 pm ENTRY: Rs 499 onwards LOG: www.insider.in

BOLLYWOOD COMEDY NIGHT

This is a show where, as the name suggests, the world of comedy and Hindi films collide. At Bollywood Comedy Night, comedians will strictly joke only about Bollywood movies and everything and everyone associated with this industry. The show will be hosted by comic Siddhartha Shetty and feature Shashi Dhiman, Shridhar V, Adesh Nichit, Devanshi Shah and Rajnish Kumar. WHERE: The Juhu Studio WHEN: 8.30 pm ENTRY: Rs 349 LOG: www.bookmyshow.com

Go for a book discussion

Sudhanva Deshpande’s book Halla Bol narrates the story of playwright Safdar Hashmi. In 1989, while performing a street play with his group Janam on the outskirts of Delhi, he was attacked and eventually succumbed due to his injuries. The book highlights how one man’s death and life are intertwined with others around him. At the discussion, Deshpande will be joined by author Shanta Gokhale, journalist P Sainath and thespian Moloyashree Hashmi. The event will also see Janam perform their iconic play Machine. WHERE: Goethe-Institut/Max Mueller Bhavan, Kala Ghoda WHEN: 6 pm ENTRY: Free CALL: 22027710

Catch a play at the museum

Written, directed and performed by Ulka Mayur, Cast Off All Shame is an engaging one-woman play. In it, the celebrated Bhakti poet Janabai comes to life, and becomes an agony aunt to the modern woman. While suggesting solutions to the problems of these women, Janabai speaks about liberalising the Bhakti movement, recounting the poetry by female mystic poets such as Karaikal Ammaiyar, Akka Mahadevi and Lal Ded. This act tries to address these issues through tongue-incheek observations. WHERE: Dr Bhau Daji Lad Museum, Byculla WHEN: 6 pm ENTRY: Free CALL: 23731234

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

BOOK NOW - HAPI Brewing Co

Celebrate Women’s Day with food, music and drinks at this restaurant in Dahisar. Your gang can groove to the beats of DJ Rewind. HAPI Brewing Co’s has arranged for a special menu. If your need something to get you going at the dance floor, head to the bar and choose from an extensive beer menu. WHERE: HAPI Brewing Co., Dahisar WHEN: Mar 8, noon onwards ENTRY: Rs 500 (for adults), Rs 250 (for children above 7) and free for children below 7 CALL: 8104803915

MUST ATTEND - The Influencer School

This is a workshop for all aspiring influencers in the city. On the eve of Women’s Day, experts such as Aanam Chasmawala (in pic), founder of What When Wear, Natasha Patel, senior beauty editor at MissMalini and Aaliya Amrin, content creator and co-founder of By The Gram will share their success stories as well as tips on what you can do to become a successful influencer. The session will focus on how to get noticed, break free from the curse of barter deals and actually get paid for your efforts. WHERE: Femina FLAUNT Studio Salon, Khar WHEN: Mar 7, 10 am ENTRY: Rs 3,000 LOG: www.insider.in

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

THE GIG GUIDE - PARTY HARD THIS WEEKEND AT THE HOTTEST GIGS IN THE CITY

Good vibes, great sounds

Let your hair down, grab a drink and enjoy groovy tunes at these gigs.

INDIEPENDENT WOMEN

Some of the best women artists that the indie scene in India has to offer will be on stage tomorrow, as part of a Women’s Day musical extravaganza. Curated by singer-songwriter Shannon Donald, who will also be performing at the do, the line-up includes artists such as Aditi Ramesh, Kamakshi Khanna, Kanchan Daniel and Suzanne Dmello. Tomorrow, 9 pm. Flea Bazaar Cafe, Lower Parel. Call 7045939983 for entry details

FAUZIA

The British-Somali DJ is one of the rising stars of the club scene in London. The young DJ has already made her Boiler Room debut, and also hosts a radio show on NTS, a popular online radio station and media platform in the UK. Expect high energy club tracks from her, whether it is house, techno or footwork. Tomorrow, 7 pm. Raasta Bombay, Khar. Rs 499. Visit: www.skillboxes.com

STU LARSEN

The Aussie singer-songwriter is currently on a 11-city tour of the world in March, which also spans across 11 different countries. This Saturday, he will stop by Mumbai to perform his signature raw, folk pop songs, which are inspired by his love of travel. After Mumbai, he will be jetting off to countries such as Botswana, Turkey, Mexico, USA, England and Argentina. Tomorrow, 9 pm. Rule 34, Kandivali. Free entry. Visit:www.rule34.in

LYDIA HENDRIKJE

For the past few years, the Mumbai-based German singer and composer has enthralled audiences with her live performances — and tonight is no different. Join her as she belts out jazz hits at this intimate gig. Hendrikje, who studied jazz vocals at the Royal Conservatory in The Hague, Netherlands, in 2012, will be joined by Anurag Naidu (keys), Marios Menelaou (bass) and Aron Nyiro (drums). Tonight, 8.30 pm. One Street, above Bastian, Bandra. Free entry. RSVP: www.insider.in

NINO BROWN + MO STYLES

Catch two cool acts take turns to set the dance floor on fire at this gig. First up is Nino Brown (in pic), who loves to play dancehall, R&B, and pop hits, and often mix it up with global electronic sounds as well. She is also the founder of one of Canada’s largest inclusive dance party series, Yes Yes Y’all, and has played at the popular Boiler Room in London. Then, there is Mo Joshi, better known as Mo Styles. He used to be a vocalist for a hip-hop act in the UK during the 1990s, but now he is one of the co-founders of Azadi Records, which has acts like Prabh Deep and Seedhe Maut. Tonight, 10 pm. Bonobo, Bandra. Free entry. Call: 26055050

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

CHECK OUT - The Kirk MacDonald Generations Quartet

Award-winning Canadian jazz musician Kirk MacDonald — whose album, The Atlantic Sessions, won the 1999 Juno Award for Best Mainstream Jazz Album — will be performing at a special recital in the city this Sunday.

The artist recorded his 15th album, Generations, in 2018, which features a collection of Great American Songbook tunes and jazz standards. The album as well as Sunday’s performance is special for Kirk because both feature his daughter, clarinettist Virginia Macdonald. “It’s a wonderful experience working with Virginia. She is an inspiration as a musician and she brings her own voice to the music and maintains an organic, spontaneous and interactive approach to playing music,” says Kirk, who has worked with musicians such as John Taylor and Rosemary Clooney.

Virginia started playing the clarinet at the age of seven and realised that she wants to pursue music professionally. “When you grow up surrounded by music, it becomes a significant part of your life, whether you choose to play it yourself or not. For me, my connection to music has always been tied in with being able to play it myself,” she says. The young musician says that Jimmy Giuffre is one of her favourite clarinettists and has influenced her music.

The Kirk MacDonald Generations Quartet (which also includes bassist Neil Swainson and drummer Morgan Childs) will perform contemporary original music, mixed with jazz standards and music from the Great American Songbook. They will play tunes such as “On Green Dolphin Street”, “I’ve Never Been in Love Before” and “Body and Soul”.

The Kirk MacDonald Generations Quartet will perform at Experimental Theatre, NCPA, Nariman Point on Mar 8, 7 pm. Entry: Rs 500 onwards. Visit: www.bookmyshow.com
